greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of representations of n as a minimal number of squares, A002828(n).
comment: By Lagrange's four square theorem, the minimal number of squares required to represent a number is 4 or less. See A141490 for the numbers k that have n minimal representations.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: 27 has the following representations as the sum of 4 or fewer squares: 1+1+25, 9+9+9, and 1+1+9+16. The minimal number of squares is 3 and there are 2 such representations.  Hence a(27)=2.
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Jan 19 2011
